author: Laura Hughes
title: Jeremy Corbyn keen to offer Ed Miliband a position in his Shadow Cabinet
text:
Jeremy Corbyn keen to offer Ed Miliband a position in his Shadow Cabinet Ed Miliband, the former Labour Leader Credit: EPA/FACUNDO ARRIZABALAGA Laura Hughes , Political Correspondent 3 February 2017 • 10:16am 
J eremy Corbyn is set to offer Ed Miliband a position in his Shadow Cabinet, according to reports. 
The former Labour leader could replace Clive Lewis as Shadow Business Secretary if he quits over his Brexit rebellion. 
Mr Lewis, who defied Mr Corbyn and voted against the Government's Article 50 bill on Wednesday, has said he is willing to resign if ordered to. Britain's Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn Credit: DARREN STAPLES 
I t is understood that Mr Corbyn has always been keen for Mr Miliband to take up a role in his top team. 
A Labour source told the Daily Mirror: “They really want Ed to come back. They’ve wanted him for quite a while and in some ways this is the ideal brief.” 
Speaking earlier this week, Mr Lewis said he would be prepared to "walk" walk away from the Shadow Cabinet and vote against the Labour three-line whip. Watch | Miliband: Corbyn's position is untenable 00:59 
H e told the Eastern Daily Press: “Allowing parliament to scrutinise and put down red lines on key areas as I have always said – workers’ rights, the environment, proper scrutiny and transparency – is critical. 
“If the Government won’t accept those, it doesn’t have a mandate for a ‘cliff edge vandalism Brexit’ and I will vote against, whatever the consequences are for me with my personal position.” 
It comes after reports that Labour has lost thousands of members since Mr Corbyn instructed MPs to vote in favour of triggering Brexit negotiations. Jeremy Corbyn and his predecessor Ed Miliband Credit: Stefan Rousseau/PA 
A ccording to figures handed to the New Statesman magazine, more than 7,000 members have resigned. 
A large number of those who have left are understood to live in London, where the majority of voters backed Remain in the referendum. 
The Labour leader faces his third reshuffle in 18 months after 17 serving frontbenchers defied his orders and four members of his front bench team quit.
